assessments.status_rationale: Today’s news includes reporting that JPMorgan says banks could fight a Trump credit-card rate cap proposal, which signals political momentum around an APR cap. However, the bullet does not provide clear evidence that a bill has been formally introduced in either chamber with explicit statutory text capping APRs at 10% or less, so the prediction cannot be marked correct yet.
No item in today’s bullets references the 2025 Shared National Credit (SNC) review or any 2026 Q1 GSIB earnings-call/10‑Q language, and the relevant reporting period is still ahead.
Today’s bullets do not provide market-close data indicating DXY closed below 95.0, nor do they report a move of that magnitude; the deadline remains months away.
No LBMA Gold Price (PM) fixing levels are provided in today’s bullets, and there is no clear evidence that gold has printed ≥10% above the 2026-01-12 LBMA PM baseline.

Although several items relate to Iran (protests, geopolitics, oil), none indicate an OFAC sanctions action designating 3+ non-Iranian parties tied to Iranian petroleum/petrochemical sales, shipping, or evasion.
Today’s bullets contain no information about an iOS 19 developer beta or Apple-documented Siri integration using Google Gemini.
No Alphabet SEC filing, earnings-call excerpt, or other disclosure is cited today that quantifies an Apple-related Gemini/Siri consideration at an annualized value ≥$20B.
CNBC reports Meta VR layoffs and studio closures, but this does not establish the year-over-year change in Reality Labs operating loss for Meta’s 2026 Q2 earnings release (which will occur later).
No bulletin reports a top-20 U.S. health system announcing production deployment of an OpenAI/Torch-branded healthcare data workflow product integrated with its EHR/clinical data platform.
There is no mention in today’s bullets of ONC publishing an RFI/draft guidance/proposed rule addressing AI transparency/auditability/safety requirements for certified EHR technology.
